member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.NativeMethods.Kernel32
member.summary: The name of the kernel32 library

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.NativeMethods.LoadLibrary(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the specified module into the address space of the calling process. The specified module may cause other modules to be loaded.

param.name: dllToLoad
param.para: The name of the module. This can be either a library module (a .dll file) or an executable module (an .exe file). The name specified is the file name of the module and is not related to the name stored in the library module itself, as specified by the LIBRARY keyword in the module-definition (.def) file.
If the string specifies a full path, the function searches only that path for the module.
If the string specifies a relative path or a module name without a path, the function uses a standard search strategy to find the module; for more information, see the Remarks.

If the function cannot find the module, the function fails. When specifying a path, be sure to use backslashes (\), not forward slashes (/). For more information about paths, see Naming a File or Directory.

If the string specifies a module name without a path and the file name extension is omitted, the function appends the default library extension .dll to the module name. To prevent the function from appending .dll to the module name, include a trailing point character (.) in the module name string.

member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is a handle to the module. If the function fails, the return value is . To get extended error information, call .

member.summary: One of the "transform operations"

member.summary: The bitwise OR of one of more of the "transform options"

member.name: P:TurboJpegWrapper.tjtransform.data
member.summary: Arbitrary data that can be accessed within the body of the callback function

member.name: P:TurboJpegWrapper.tjtransform.customFilter
member.summary: A callback function that can be used to modify the DCT coefficients after they are losslessly transformed but before they are transcoded to a new JPEG image. This allows for custom filters or other transformations to be applied in the frequency domain.

member.name: T:TurboJpegWrapper.CustomFilter
member.summary: A callback function that can be used to modify the DCT coefficients after they are losslessly transformed but before they are transcoded to a new JPEG image. This allows for custom filters or other transformations to be applied in the frequency domain.
member.param: Pointer to an array of transformed DCT coefficients. (NOTE this pointer is not guaranteed to be valid once the callback returns, so applications wishing to hand off the DCT coefficients to another function or library should make a copy of them within the body of the callback.)

structure containing the width and height of the array pointed to by as well as its offset relative to the component plane. TurboJPEG implementations may choose to split each component plane into multiple DCT coefficient arrays and call the callback function once for each array.
structure containing the width and height of the component plane to which belongs
ID number of the component plane to which belongs (Y, Cb, and Cr have, respectively, ID's of 0, 1, and 2 in typical JPEG images.)
ID number of the transformed image to which belongs. This is the same as the index of the transform in the "transforms" array that was passed to
A pointer to a structure that specifies the parameters and/or cropping region for this transform
member.returns: 0 if the callback was successful, or -1 if an error occurred.
member.remarks:
Original signature is:
int customFilter(short *coeffs, tjregion arrayRegion, tjregion planeRegion, int componentIndex, int transformIndex, struct tjtransform * transform)

member.name: T:TurboJpegWrapper.TJColorSpaces
member.summary: JPEG colorspaces

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJColorSpaces.TJCS_RGB
member.summary: RGB colorspace. When compressing the JPEG image, the R, G, and B components in the source image are reordered into image planes, but no colorspace conversion or subsampling is performed. RGB JPEG images can be decompressed to any of the extended RGB pixel formats or grayscale, but they cannot be decompressed to YUV images.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJColorSpaces.TJCS_YCbCr
member.summary: YCbCr colorspace. YCbCr is not an absolute colorspace but rather a mathematical transformation of RGB designed solely for storage and transmission. YCbCr images must be converted to RGB before they can actually be displayed. In the YCbCr colorspace, the Y (luminance) component represents the black-and-white portion of the original image, and the Cb and Cr (chrominance) components represent the color portion of the original image. Originally, the analog equivalent of this transformation allowed the same signal to drive both black-and-white and color televisions, but JPEG images use YCbCr primarily because it allows the color data to be optionally subsampled for the purposes of reducing bandwidth or disk space. YCbCr is the most common JPEG colorspace, and YCbCr JPEG images can be compressed from and decompressed to any of the extended RGB pixel formats or grayscale, or they can be decompressed to YUV planar images.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJColorSpaces.TJCS_GRAY
member.summary: Grayscale colorspace. The JPEG image retains only the luminance data (Y component), and any color data from the source image is discarded. Grayscale JPEG images can be compressed from and decompressed to any of the extended RGB pixel formats or grayscale, or they can be decompressed to YUV planar images.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJColorSpaces.TJCS_CMYK
member.summary: CMYK colorspace. When compressing the JPEG image, the C, M, Y, and K components in the source image are reordered into image planes, but no colorspace conversion or subsampling is performed. CMYK JPEG images can only be decompressed to CMYK pixels.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJColorSpaces.TJCS_YCCK
member.summary: YCCK colorspace. YCCK (AKA "YCbCrK") is not an absolute colorspace but rather a mathematical transformation of CMYK designed solely for storage and transmission. It is to CMYK as YCbCr is to RGB. CMYK pixels can be reversibly transformed into YCCK, and as with YCbCr, the chrominance components in the YCCK pixels can be subsampled without incurring major perceptual loss. YCCK JPEG images can only be compressed from and decompressed to CMYK pixels.

member.name: T:TurboJpegWrapper.TJSubsamplingOptions
member.summary:
Chrominance subsampling options.
When pixels are converted from RGB to YCbCr (see #TJCS_YCbCr) or from CMYK to YCCK (see #TJCS_YCCK) as part of the JPEG compression process, some of the Cb and Cr (chrominance) components can be discarded or averaged together to produce a smaller image with little perceptible loss of image clarity (the human eye is more sensitive to small changes in brightness than to small changes in color.) This is called "chrominance subsampling".

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJSubsamplingOptions.TJSAMP_444
member.summary: 4:4:4 chrominance subsampling (no chrominance subsampling). The JPEG or * YUV image will contain one chrominance component for every pixel in the source image.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJSubsamplingOptions.TJSAMP_422
member.summary: 4:2:2 chrominance subsampling. The JPEG or YUV image will contain one chrominance component for every 2x1 block of pixels in the source image.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJSubsamplingOptions.TJSAMP_420
member.summary: 4:2:0 chrominance subsampling. The JPEG or YUV image will contain one chrominance component for every 2x2 block of pixels in the source image.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJSubsamplingOptions.TJSAMP_GRAY
member.summary: Grayscale. The JPEG or YUV image will contain no chrominance components.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJSubsamplingOptions.TJSAMP_440
member.summary: 4:4:0 chrominance subsampling. The JPEG or YUV image will contain one chrominance component for every 1x2 block of pixels in the source image.
member.remarks: 4:4:0 subsampling is not fully accelerated in libjpeg-turbo.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJSubsamplingOptions.TJSAMP_411
member.summary: 4:1:1 chrominance subsampling. The JPEG or YUV image will contain one chrominance component for every 4x1 block of pixels in the source image. JPEG images compressed with 4:1:1 subsampling will be almost exactly the same size as those compressed with 4:2:0 subsampling, and in the aggregate, both subsampling methods produce approximately the same perceptual quality. However, 4:1:1 is better able to reproduce sharp horizontal features.
member.remarks: 4:1:1 subsampling is not fully accelerated in libjpeg-turbo.

member.name: T:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats
member.summary: Pixel formats

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_RGB
member.summary: RGB pixel format. The red, green, and blue components in the image are stored in 3-byte pixels in the order R, G, B from lowest to highest byte address within each pixel.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_BGR
member.summary: BGR pixel format. The red, green, and blue components in the image are stored in 3-byte pixels in the order B, G, R from lowest to highest byte address within each pixel.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_RGBX
member.summary: RGBX pixel format. The red, green, and blue components in the image are stored in 4-byte pixels in the order R, G, B from lowest to highest byte address within each pixel. The X component is ignored when compressing and undefined when decompressing.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_BGRX
member.summary: BGRX pixel format. The red, green, and blue components in the image are stored in 4-byte pixels in the order B, G, R from lowest to highest byte address within each pixel. The X component is ignored when compressing and undefined when decompressing.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_XBGR
member.summary: XBGR pixel format. The red, green, and blue components in the image are stored in 4-byte pixels in the order R, G, B from highest to lowest byte address within each pixel. The X component is ignored when compressing and undefined when decompressing.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_XRGB
member.summary: XRGB pixel format. The red, green, and blue components in the image are stored in 4-byte pixels in the order B, G, R from highest to lowest byte address within each pixel. The X component is ignored when compressing and undefined when decompressing.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_GRAY
member.summary: Grayscale pixel format. Each 1-byte pixel represents a luminance (brightness) level from 0 to 255.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_RGBA
member.summary: RGBA pixel format. This is the same as , except that when decompressing, the X component is guaranteed to be 0xFF, which can be interpreted as an opaque alpha channel.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_BGRA
member.summary: BGRA pixel format. This is the same as , except that when decompressing, the X component is guaranteed to be 0xFF, which can be interpreted as an opaque alpha channel.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_ABGR
member.summary: ABGR pixel format. This is the same as , except that when decompressing, the X component is guaranteed to be 0xFF, which can be interpreted as an opaque alpha channel.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_ARGB
member.summary: ARGB pixel format. This is the same as , except that when decompressing, the X component is guaranteed to be 0xFF, which can be interpreted as an opaque alpha channel.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJPixelFormats.TJPF_CMYK
member.summary: CMYK pixel format. Unlike RGB, which is an additive color model used primarily for display, CMYK (Cyan/Magenta/Yellow/Key) is a subtractive color model used primarily for printing. In the CMYK color model, the value of each color component typically corresponds to an amount of cyan, magenta, yellow, or black ink that is applied to a white background. In order to convert between CMYK and RGB, it is necessary to use a color management system (CMS.) A CMS will attempt to map colors within the printer's gamut to perceptually similar colors in the display's gamut and vice versa, but the mapping is typically not 1:1 or reversible, nor can it be defined with a simple formula. Thus, such a conversion is out of scope for a codec library. However, the TurboJPEG API allows for compressing CMYK pixels into a YCCK JPEG image (see #TJCS_YCCK) and decompressing YCCK JPEG images into CMYK pixels.

member.name: T:TurboJpegWrapper.TJFlags
member.summary: Flags for turbo jpeg

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJFlags.NONE
member.summary: Flags not set

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJFlags.BOTTOMUP
member.summary: The uncompressed source/destination image is stored in bottom-up (Windows, OpenGL) order, not top-down (X11) order.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJFlags.FASTUPSAMPLE
member.summary: When decompressing an image that was compressed using chrominance subsampling, use the fastest chrominance upsampling algorithm available in the underlying codec. The default is to use smooth upsampling, which creates a smooth transition between neighboring chrominance components in order to reduce upsampling artifacts in the decompressed image.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJFlags.NOREALLOC
member.summary: Disable buffer (re)allocation. If passed to or #tjTransform(), this flag will cause those functions to generate an error if the JPEG image buffer is invalid or too small rather than attempting to allocate or reallocate that buffer. This reproduces the behavior of earlier versions of TurboJPEG.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJFlags.FASTDCT
member.summary: Use the fastest DCT/IDCT algorithm available in the underlying codec. The default if this flag is not specified is implementation-specific. For example, the implementation of TurboJPEG for libjpeg[-turbo] uses the fast algorithm by default when compressing, because this has been shown to have only a very slight effect on accuracy, but it uses the accurate algorithm when decompressing, because this has been shown to have a larger effect.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJFlags.ACCURATEDCT
member.summary: Use the most accurate DCT/IDCT algorithm available in the underlying codec. The default if this flag is not specified is implementation-specific. For example, the implementation of TurboJPEG for libjpeg[-turbo] uses the fast algorithm by default when compressing, because this has been shown to have only a very slight effect on accuracy, but it uses the accurate algorithm when decompressing, because this has been shown to have a larger effect.

member.name: T:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOperations
member.summary: Transform operations for

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOperations.TJXOP_NONE
member.summary: Do not transform the position of the image pixels

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOperations.TJXOP_HFLIP
member.summary: Flip (mirror) image horizontally. This transform is imperfect if there are any partial MCU blocks on the right edge (see .)

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOperations.TJXOP_VFLIP
member.summary: Flip (mirror) image vertically. This transform is imperfect if there are any partial MCU blocks on the bottom edge (see .)

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOperations.TJXOP_TRANSPOSE
member.summary: Transpose image (flip/mirror along upper left to lower right axis.) This transform is always perfect.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOperations.TJXOP_TRANSVERSE
member.summary: Transverse transpose image (flip/mirror along upper right to lower left axis.) This transform is imperfect if there are any partial MCU blocks in the image (see .)

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOperations.TJXOP_ROT90
member.summary: Rotate image clockwise by 90 degrees. This transform is imperfect if there are any partial MCU blocks on the bottom edge (.)

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOperations.TJXOP_ROT180
member.summary: Rotate image 180 degrees. This transform is imperfect if there are any partial MCU blocks in the image (see .)

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOperations.TJXOP_ROT270
member.summary: Rotate image counter-clockwise by 90 degrees. This transform is imperfect if there are any partial MCU blocks on the right edge (see .)

member.name: T:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOptions
member.summary: Transformation options

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOptions.PERFECT
member.summary: This option will cause to return an error if the transform is not perfect. Lossless transforms operate on MCU blocks, whose size depends on the level of chrominance subsampling used If the image's width or height is not evenly divisible by the MCU block size, then there will be partial MCU blocks on the right and/or bottom edges. It is not possible to move these partial MCU blocks to the top or left of the image, so any transform that would require that is "imperfect." If this option is not specified, then any partial MCU blocks that cannot be transformed will be left in place, which will create odd-looking strips on the right or bottom edge of the image.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOptions.TRIM
member.summary: This option will cause to discard any partial MCU blocks that cannot be transformed.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOptions.CROP
member.summary: This option will enable lossless cropping. See for more information.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOptions.GRAY
member.summary: This option will discard the color data in the input image and produce a grayscale output image.

member.name: F:TurboJpegWrapper.TJTransformOptions.NOOUTPUT
member.summary: This option will prevent from outputting a JPEG image for this particular transform (this can be used in conjunction with a custom filter to capture the transformed DCT coefficients without transcoding them.)

Bytes per line in the source image. Normally, this should be width * BytesPerPixel if the image is unpadded, or TJPAD(width * BytesPerPixel if each line of the image is padded to the nearest 32-bit boundary, as is the case for Windows bitmaps. You can also be clever and use this parameter to skip lines, etc. Setting this parameter to 0 is the equivalent of setting it to width * BytesPerPixel.

Pixel format of the source image (see "Pixel formats")

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjInitCompress
member.summary: Create a TurboJPEG compressor instance.
member.returns: handle to the newly-created instance, or if an error occurred (see )

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjCompress2(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr@,System.UInt64@,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compress an RGB, grayscale, or CMYK image into a JPEG image.
member.param: A handle to a TurboJPEG compressor or transformer instance
Pointer to an image buffer containing RGB, grayscale, or CMYK pixels to be compressed. This buffer is not modified.
Width (in pixels) of the source image

Bytes per line in the source image. Normally, this should be width * tjPixelSize[pixelFormat] if the image is unpadded, or TJPAD(width * tjPixelSize[pixelFormat]) if each line of the image is padded to the nearest 32-bit boundary, as is the case for Windows bitmaps. You can also be clever and use this parameter to skip lines, etc. Setting this parameter to 0 is the equivalent of setting it to width * tjPixelSize[pixelFormat].
Height (in pixels) of the source image
Pixel format of the source image (see "Pixel formats")

Address of a pointer to an image buffer that will receive the JPEG image. TurboJPEG has the ability to reallocate the JPEG buffer to accommodate the size of the JPEG image. Thus, you can choose to:
pre-allocate the JPEG buffer with an arbitrary size using and let TurboJPEG grow the buffer as needed
set to NULL to tell TurboJPEG to allocate the buffer for you
pre-allocate the buffer to a "worst case" size determined by calling . This should ensure that the buffer never has to be re-allocated (setting guarantees this.).
If you choose option 1, should be set to the size of your pre-allocated buffer. In any case, unless you have set , you should always check upon return from this function, as it may have changed.

Pointer to an unsigned long variable that holds the size of the JPEG image buffer. If points to a pre-allocated buffer, then should be set to the size of the buffer. Upon return, will contain the size of the JPEG image (in bytes.) If points to a JPEG image buffer that is being reused from a previous call to one of the JPEG compression functions, then is ignored.
The level of chrominance subsampling to be used when generating the JPEG image (see "Chrominance subsampling options".)
The image quality of the generated JPEG image (1 = worst, 100 = best)
The bitwise OR of one or more of the "flags"
member.returns: 0 if successful, or -1 if an error occurred (see )

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjBufSize(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: The maximum size of the buffer (in bytes) required to hold a JPEG image with the given parameters. The number of bytes returned by this function is larger than the size of the uncompressed source image. The reason for this is that the JPEG format uses 16-bit coefficients, and it is thus possible for a very high-quality JPEG image with very high-frequency content to expand rather than compress when converted to the JPEG format. Such images represent a very rare corner case, but since there is no way to predict the size of a JPEG image prior to compression, the corner case has to be handled.
member.param: Width (in pixels) of the image
Height (in pixels) of the image
The level of chrominance subsampling to be used when generating the JPEG image(see "Chrominance subsampling options".)
member.returns: The maximum size of the buffer (in bytes) required to hold the image, or -1 if the arguments are out of bounds.

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjInitDecompress
member.summary: Create a TurboJPEG decompressor instance.
member.returns: A handle to the newly-created instance, or NULL if an error occurred(see )

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjDecompressHeader(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.UInt64,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Retrieve information about a JPEG image without decompressing it.
member.param: A handle to a TurboJPEG decompressor or transformer instance
Pointer to a buffer containing a JPEG image. This buffer is not modified.
Size of the JPEG image (in bytes)
Pointer to an integer variable that will receive the width (in pixels) of the JPEG image
Pointer to an integer variable that will receive the height (in pixels) of the JPEG image
Pointer to an integer variable that will receive the level of chrominance subsampling used when the JPEG image was compressed (see "Chrominance subsampling options".)
Pointer to an integer variable that will receive one of the JPEG colorspace constants, indicating the colorspace of the JPEG image(see "JPEG colorspaces".)
member.returns: 0 if successful, or -1 if an error occurred (see )

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjGetScalingFactors(System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns a list of fractional scaling factors that the JPEG decompressor in this implementation of TurboJPEG supports.
member.param: Pointer to an integer variable that will receive the number of elements in the list
member.returns: A pointer to a list of fractional scaling factors, or if an error is encountered (see )

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjDecompress(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.UInt64,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Decompress a JPEG image to an RGB, grayscale, or CMYK image.
member.param: A handle to a TurboJPEG decompressor or transformer instance
Pointer to a buffer containing the JPEG image to decompress. This buffer is not modified.
Size of the JPEG image (in bytes)

Pointer to an image buffer that will receive the decompressed image. This buffer should normally be pitch * scaledHeight bytes in size, where scaledHeight can be determined by calling with the JPEG image height and one of the scaling factors returned by . The pointer may also be used to decompress into a specific region of a larger buffer.

Desired width (in pixels) of the destination image. If this is different than the width of the JPEG image being decompressed, then TurboJPEG will use scaling in the JPEG decompressor to generate the largest possible image that will fit within the desired width. If is set to 0, then only the height will be considered when determining the scaled image size.

Bytes per line in the destination image. Normally, this is scaledWidth* tjPixelSize[pixelFormat] if the decompressed image is unpadded, else TJPAD(scaledWidth * tjPixelSize[pixelFormat]) if each line of the decompressed image is padded to the nearest 32-bit boundary, as is the case for Windows bitmaps.
Note: scaledWidth can be determined by calling with the JPEG image width and one of the scaling factors returned by
You can also be clever and use the pitch parameter to skip lines, etc. Setting this parameter to 0 is the equivalent of setting it to scaledWidth* tjPixelSize[pixelFormat].

Desired height (in pixels) of the destination image. If this is different than the height of the JPEG image being decompressed, then TurboJPEG will use scaling in the JPEG decompressor to generate the largest possible image that will fit within the desired height. If is set to 0, then only the width will be considered when determining the scaled image size.
Pixel format of the destination image (see "Pixel formats".)
The bitwise OR of one or more of the "flags"
member.returns: 0 if successful, or -1 if an error occurred (see )

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjAlloc(System.Int32)
member.summary: Allocate an image buffer for use with TurboJPEG. You should always use this function to allocate the JPEG destination buffer(s) for and unless you are disabling automatic buffer (re)allocation (by setting .)
member.param: The number of bytes to allocate
member.returns: A pointer to a newly-allocated buffer with the specified number of bytes

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjFree(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Free an image buffer previously allocated by TurboJPEG. You should always use this function to free JPEG destination buffer(s) that were automatically (re)allocated by or or that were manually allocated using .
member.param: Address of the buffer to free

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjInitTransform
member.summary: Create a new TurboJPEG transformer instance
member.returns: @return a handle to the newly-created instance, or NULL if an error occurred(see )

member.name: M:TurboJpegWrapper.TurboJpegImport.tjTransform(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.UInt64,System.Int32,System.IntPtr[],System.UInt64[],System.IntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary: Losslessly transform a JPEG image into another JPEG image. Lossless transforms work by moving the raw DCT coefficients from one JPEG image structure to another without altering the values of the coefficients. While this is typically faster than decompressing the image, transforming it, and re-compressing it, lossless transforms are not free. Each lossless transform requires reading and performing Huffman decoding on all of the coefficients in the source image, regardless of the size of the destination image. Thus, this function provides a means of generating multiple transformed images from the same source or applying multiple transformations simultaneously, in order to eliminate the need to read the source coefficients multiple times.
member.param: A handle to a TurboJPEG transformer instance
Pointer to a buffer containing the JPEG source image to transform.This buffer is not modified.
Size of the JPEG source image (in bytes)
The number of transformed JPEG images to generate

Pointer to an array of n image buffers. [i] will receive a JPEG image that has been transformed using the parameters in [i] TurboJPEG has the ability to reallocate the JPEG buffer to accommodate the size of the JPEG image. Thus, you can choose to:
pre-allocate the JPEG buffer with an arbitrary size using and let TurboJPEG grow the buffer as needed
set [i] to NULL to tell TurboJPEG to allocate the buffer for you
pre-allocate the buffer to a "worst case" size determined by calling . This should ensure that the buffer never has to be re-allocated (setting guarantees this.).
If you choose option 1, [i] should be set to the size of your pre-allocated buffer. In any case, unless you have set , you should always check [i] upon return from this function, as it may have changed.

Pointer to an array of unsigned long variables that will receive the actual sizes (in bytes) of each transformed JPEG image. If [i] points to a pre-allocated buffer, then [i] should be set to the size of the buffer. Upon return, [i] will contain the size of the JPEG image (in bytes.)
Pointer to an array of structures, each of which specifies the transform parameters and/or cropping region for the corresponding transformed output image.
flags the bitwise OR of one or more of the "flags"
member.returns: 0 if successful, or -1 if an error occurred (see )
